Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution based on religion (Jewish)
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Legal_Framework: International refugee law, Canadian immigration law
Evidence_Requirement: Burden of proof on applicants to demonstrate state inability to protect
Decision_Outcome: Applicants failed to meet burden of proof regarding state protection
Institutional_Action: CRDD review and decision, followed by judicial review
Government_Body_or_Authority: Convention Refugee Determination Division (CRDD), Canadian courts
Exemptions_or_Defenses_Cited: State protection available despite imperfect enforcement
Evidence_Type: Credible testimony of harassment, discrimination, and physical assaults
Nature_of_Participation: Applicants as claimants, state as respondent
Protected_Group: Jewish individuals, members of a particular social group or religion
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Protection_Claim: Need for international protection due to lack of effective state protection in Ukraine
State_Protection_Assessment: CRDD found Ukrainian state capable of providing reasonable protection
Legal_Provision: Article 1A(2) of the 1951 Refugee Convention, incorporated via Immigration Act
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate by CRDD despite incidents
Enforcement_Action: None taken by Ukrainian authorities in specific incidents, but system deemed functional
Claimant_Status: Non-refugee status granted; applicants remain in Canada pending other avenues
Perpetrator_Entity: Private actors (individuals committing anti-Semitic acts), possible state indifference
Legal_Basis: Fear of persecution on grounds of religion
